UK's Alex Poythress tears ACL, season over

Report: Kentucky basketball's Alex Poythress tore ACL, teammates offer social-media support

UK's Alex Poythress tears ACL, season over

Kyle Tucker, ktucker@courier-journal.com 8:11 a.m. EST December 12, 2014

Kentucky forward Alex Poythress slams down two of his 6 in the second half. The University of Kentucky Men's Basketball team hosted Providence, Sunday, Nov. 30, 2014 at Rupp Arena in Lexington. Photo by Jonathan Palmer, Special to the CJ(Photo: Jonathan Palmer, Jonathan Palmer)

27 CONNECT 64 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

LEXINGTON, Ky. The top-ranked University of Kentucky basketball team has lost starting forward Alex Poythress for the season after he tore an ACL on a breakaway layup in Thursday's practice, coach John Calipari announced this morning.

"When you're coaching other people's children and these children have high aspirations and unlimited potential not only to do things for themselves but for other people I can't begin to tell you the feeling when someone gets hurt," Calipari wrote on his website. "Our team was devastated for Alex when I told them. There were tears throughout the room because this hurt them to their core. How they will respond I really don't know, but I will do my best to be there for each of these kids."

A date for surgery has not been set, but the normal timetable for recovery following ACL reconstruction is six to eight months.

Calipari said he told Poythress the same thing he told former UK star Nerlens Noel, who tore an ACL late in the 2012-13 season and still became the sixth overall pick in the NBA draft: "You're fine. If this is something crazy, you have insurance and you're a millionaire. You have even more time than Nerlens had to prepare yourself for the draft if that's what you choose to do."

Poythress could also come back to school which he has done twice after considering the draft and begin work on a master's degree as he'll graduate from UK in May.

"Alex is nearly a straight-A student and one of the greatest kids that I've ever coached," Calipari wrote on his site. "This is a big blow to our team. No one will be able to replace Alex and what he did for this team but now everybody has to do a little bit more as we try to circle the wagons."

Current and former teammates reacted on social media late Thursday night.

Sophomore shooting guard Aaron Harrison posted a picture of him and Poythress celebrating together during the team's run to the NCAA title game last season with this message: "I can't describe how much I feel for this man! He's not only my teammate but he's one of my best friends and it's really sad to see him down but on the bright side we all know that he's going to come back even stronger! Love you boy and keep your head up!"

Instagram | @theaaronice_ptp

I can't describe how much I feel for this man! He's not only my teammate but he's one of my best friends and it's really sad to see him down but on the bright side we all know that he's going to come back even stronger! Love you boy and keep your head up!

Kyle Wiltjer, who played with Poythress in 2012-13 before transferring to Gonzaga, also posted a picture of Poythress and wrote: "Never a good feeling when someone close to you gets hurt but you know you're going to come back even stronger just like Nerlens did."

Instagram | @kwiltj

Never is a good feeling when someone close to you gets hurt but know you're going to come back even stronger just like Nerlens did. Love you bro @alexthegreat22

Poythress, who was on the cover of Sports Illustrated's 2014-15 college basketball preview issue, is averaging 5.5 points, 3.8 rebounds and 1.5 blocks in 20.3 minutes per game this season. The 6-foot-8, 240-pound former McDonald's All-American has played in 81 games at UK and produced 649 points, 410 rebounds and 55 blocked shots.

Arguably the team's best pure athlete, Poythress has twice considered leaving school for the NBA draft and twice returned to hone is skills. DraftExpress.com rates him the 36th-best prospect for 2015. Because he's only played in eight games this season he missed two with an illness which is less than 30 percent of the Wildcats' schedule, Poythress should be able to apply for a medical redshirt.

As for unbeaten Kentucky, which hosts No. 21 North Carolina on Saturday, few teams are as equipped to overcome a major injury as the Cats. They have nine other projected NBA draft picks on the roster, including McDonald's All-America freshman Trey Lyles to slide into the starting lineup at small forward.

RELATED: Willis waits, ready for opportunity on deep Kentucky team.

Losing Poythress could disrupt Calipari's two-platoon plan. Derek Willis, a little-used 6-foot-9 sophomore with 3-point range, could step into the second unit or Calipari could go smaller with that group and swap in his other deep reserve, 6-foot guard Dominique Hawkins. The coach could also shuffle the groupings or scrap the plan altogether.

Calipari is scheduled to meet with the media around 2:15 p.m. on Friday.

"Our goals haven't changed. Our path just got a little tougher," the coach wrote on his website. "Say a prayer for Alex and his family. It was devastating news to all of us, but Alex is going to be fine."

Kyle Tucker can be reached at (502) 582-4361. Follow him on Twitter @KyleTucker_CJ.
